text.paragraph: This section contains a list of completed VA Outpatient Encounters for the patient and a list of Discharge Summaries, Consult Notes, and History & Physical Notes for the patient. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities.

The list of VA Outpatient Encounters shows the 150 most recent Encounter dates within the last 36 months. Each VA Outpatient Encounter may also include several notes with the complete note text. There is a limit of 10 notes for each Encounter. Follow-up visits related to the VA Encounter are not included. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities.

SURGERY CONSULT : LOCAL TITLE: COLORECTAL SURG - CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: SURGERY CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 28, 2015@12:00 ENTRY DATE: OCT 28, 2015@12:00:09 AUTHOR: LU,KIM C EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
7- yo obese (BMI 30.2) male with history of colon polyps
HISTORY PRESENT ILLNESS colonoscopy to cecum with excellent prep (4/29/14) 10 mm ascending colon lesion, +pillow sign biopsy: lipoma 8 mm pedunculated descending colon tubular adenoma at 30 cm tattoo proximal 8 mm sigmoid polyp at 22 cm, removed, not retrieved 12 mm rectal lesion at 12 cm from verge tattooed moderately differentiated, focally poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma within a tubular adenoma cancer approximated cauterized margin suspicious for lymphovascular invasion white stippled tissue lateral to base of polyp biopsy: benign
MRI pelvis (6/20/14) T2 lesion at 7 cm from verge N0 no extramural vascular invasion
CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis with oral and iv contrast (5/12/14) "Hypervascular lesions with peripheral enhancement, measuring up to 1.3 cm in diameter within the anterior subcapsular left liver lobe ...and up to 2.0 cm within the posterior liver dome... consistent...with benign liver hemangiomas; these two liver hemangiomas ...unchanged compared with the CT chest with contrast from 7/29/2004" no clear liver or lung metastases
exercise tolerance test (6/26/14) no ECG evidence of ischemia but nuclear part of test showed: "Small region of mild ischemia in the likely distal wrap around LAD, slight progression since 2007
Infarct in the basilar inferior wall likely RCA, unchanged since 2007
Left ventricular ejection fraction is normal with basilar inferior wall akinesis, unchanged since 2007"
seen by cardiology on 9/16/14, no further workup recommended
Continence Flatus: good Stool: good
Bowel Habits: 1 BM/day
Low-anterior resection with tumor-specific mesorectal excision, splenic flexure take-down, 29 EEA stapled end-to-end colorectal anastomosis, resection of umbilical hernia sac and primary repair of umbilical hernia, and construction of a right upper quadrant loop ileostomy (10/3/14) Exploratory laparotomy (for evisceration), placement of 3 external retention sutures, and fascial closure (10/10/14) transferred to CLC on 11/14/14-3/12/15
no show for clinic on 4/22/15 or today
/es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery Signed: 10/28/2015 12:03

CONSULT : LOCAL TITLE: GI - E-CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 21, 2015@12:32 ENTRY DATE: OCT 21, 2015@12:32:12 AUTHOR: COLLINS,JUDITH F EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** GI - E-CONSULT Has ADDENDA ***
Reason For Request: pt with ho rectoal cancer, sp resection/ostomy noted some blood in ostomy bag by report not orthostatic, stool green today hct stable 38(fri), 39 today ostomy area looks pink ho erosive esophagitis admis(on omeprazole) no n/v should his ostomy be scoped?
70 yo male with presumed ileostomy after resection of sigmoid/rectal cancer in 2014. BAsed on my review of the op notes, he had an end to end anastomosis of desc colon to rectal area, and had a postop complication of evisceration. I assume that now he has double barrel ileostomy??? At any rate, I don't know that he needs an urgent eval for bleeding, but would like for the ostomy nurse to look at the stoma for skin irritation, evidence of bleeding at the level of the skin. He is due for a 1 year exam post surgery ; I think he still has colon left. Will ask Dr. Lu to clarify for me.
To perform an exam through his ileostomy, he will need a regular prep and I would suggest enemas x 2 from below. (if possible). He would also benefit from MAC anesthesia since he has pain issues/meds.
/es/ JUDITH F COLLINS, MD STAFF PHYSICIAN Signed: 10/21/2015 12:40
Receipt Acknowledged By: 10/28/2015 12:01 /es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery
10/28/2015 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED Still has colon and part of rectum Double barrelled ileostomy.
/es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery Signed: 10/28/2015 12:02
Receipt Acknowledged By: * AWAITING SIGNATURE * COLLINS,JUDITH F

FN136 MN136 LN136 70YO Visit date: 10/19/15 11:15
Service Connected: NO Disabilities: (NONE RECORDED) PROBLEM LIST: --rectal cancer found on polypectomy during colonoscopy 5/14 ct abd pelvis completed today 5/12/14 being followed/evaluated by heme onc 10/3 PVAMC: Low-anterior resection (LAR) for rectal ca, with end-to-end colorectal anastomosis, and loop ileostomy; postop wound dehiscence; delirium; consultation by Psychiatry; studies noncontrib.; haloperidol added 10/10 Closure of abdominal wound dehiscence (except inferior aspect) -CAD/sp CABG 2007 SP ACTUE INFERIOR MI-elevation in inf lat leads 8/04 ANGIOGRAPHY 8/23/04 LVEF 50%, INF WALL HYPOKINETIC 80% MID RAMUS 70% LONG SGMENT PROX CX RCA N UNTIL MID-SEGMENT PDA WITH SUBTOTAL OCCLUSION(SMALL VESSEL, NO PTCA) received TNKase myalgias with simvastatin-dc'd seen 12/04 following hospitalization for stuttering cp at providence-->ett ordered 73% HR with 1 mm depression inf/lat leads admit angina PVAMC 5/05: angio with 70% ramus-stented NSTEMI 8/06--, peak troponin .13 cath 8/11/06 PTCA RCA with Taxus stent CABG 2007: (LIMA to LAD, VG to PDA and VG to OM) chest pian 11/09-->cath Providence, patent graphs NSTEMI 12/09-->med management -GERD -chronic back pain sp lumbar laminectomy 5/01 MVA 3/02: seen 3/02, Dr. Levine: ho neck and back pain, numbness in left 4th/5th fingers since mva 3/02 seen by Kaiser MD--Dr. Levine--pt wanted to be stated as disabled but no evidence on exam per notes. MRI cervical spine negative ?ho narcotic abuse --pt states he was on morphine at Kaiser but wife stole meds so he then went cold turkey pain clinic at Kaiser per pt pain contract signed 12/29/04 function per pt--does nothing without meds, able to do IADL's and some walking with med. -htn -chronic sinusitis sp surgery for deviated septum -right knee surgery secondary to mva -tonsillectomy -renal cyst CT with exophytic hypodnesity in right kidney ultrasound 9/04 cw cysts -developed extreme rectal pain 8/04 during hospitalization for MI a.tuality community hospital b.flex sig nl c.required narcotics, gabapentin, decadron with improvement(narcotics dc prior to discharge) eval by neurology-Dr. Chen d.ct pelvis without retroperitoneal bleed e.mri 8/17/04 lumbar spine: intradural nonenhancing mass centered behind upper S2. I suspect a sequestered disk fragment is most likley. S3 and below root impingement would be expected L5 defects with subluuxation and pedicle screw fusion. Severe L5-S1 disc degentereation additional djd as described(see scanned document) exam wnl other than pain dc on decodron 2 mg qd(was tapered), gabapentin 800 q6, celebrex 200 bid discussed with Dr. Chen(neurology) 503-681-0816 f. MRI 10/04: Impression: 1. STATUS-POST L4-S1 POSTERIOR FUSION. L5-S1 GRADE 2 SPONDYLOLISTHESIS WITH BILATERAL SEVERE L5-S1 NEURAL FORAMINAL STENOSIS.
2. PROBABLE IRREGULARITY OF THE DISTAL THECAL SAC AT THE S2 LEVEL. NO DEFINITE INTRADURAL NONENHANCING LESION AT THE S2 LEVEL ON THE CURRENT EXAM. RECOMMEND OBTAINING OUTSIDE MRI LUMBAR SPINE SO AN ADDENDUM REPORT CAN BE SUBMITTED. CPRS DOES NOT STATE WHERE OUTSIDE MRI LUMBAR SPINE WAS OBTAINED. THEIR REFERRING CLINICIAN LIKELY HAS THIS INFORMATION. request made to pt to get previous MRI
-Rhabdomyolysis and ARF 11/06 ? due to trauma peak CPK 9700, cr 4.5 -IDA identified 11/09 no showed GI multiple times rereferred 1/10 colonoscopy/egd--colonoscopy-pedunctutlated polyp 2/10, needs 2 day prep and repeat egd esophagitis 2005
MEDS: Active Medications: 1) Albuterol 90mcg (cfc-f) 200d oral inhl inhale 2 puffs active by mouth every 4 hours as needed for breathing (each inhaler contains 200 puffs) for shortness of breath 2) Aspirin 81mg ec tab take one tablet by mouth every day 3) Atorvastatin calcium 20mg tab take one tablet by mouth every evening to lower cholesterol *avoid grapefruit products with this medicine 4) Metoprolol tartrate 25mg tab take one tablet by mouth twice a day for heart disease 5) Omeprazole 20mg ec cap take one capsule by mouth active twice a day for erosive esophagitis 6) Skin barrier wipe use wipe topically to affected area as directed [47123] 7) Trazodone hcl 50mg tab take one tablet by mouth at bedtime as needed for sleep
Adult Preventive Care/Health Promotion
Immunizations: Pneumovax(>65 or chronic illness) Prevnar(>65, sig immunosuppression)-if given must wait 8 weeks to give PNX) Tetanus Tdap Influenza Zostavax IMMUNIZATIONS: 11/01/07 INFLUENZA, UNSPECIFIED FORMULATION 04/26/07 PNEUMOCOCCAL, UNSPECIFIED FORMULATION 11/06/08 FLU,3 YRS (HISTORICAL) 04/26/07 PNEUMOCOCCAL POLYSACCHARIDE PPV23
diabetes screen No HEMOGLOBIN A1C in the last 1Y Lipid screen Lipid Panel: 09/20/13 14:12 CHOLESTEROL 225 HDL CHOLESTEROL 42 LDL-CHOL CALC 127 TRIGLYCERIDES 282 H
REASON FOR VISIT/CHIEF COMPLAINT: fu pt seen firday co blood in ostomy bag. eval in ecu providence city136 andhct was 39, pt was wearing a clear bag according to him but has now been using an opaque bag. does say that he noted some lbood that day but hasn't since is also out of ostomy supplies, has been getting form OHSU pt denies sig diarryhea in bag, black tarry stool, no abd pain or heartburn
continues to co back pain , but not motivated to improve activiyt, but does want somehting for the pain, asks about "oxycontin".
unclear what meds pt is taking, taking nothing for pain per him including acetominophen bc doesn't work
PE:VITALS: Vitals per nurse's entry: Temperature: 97.7 F [36.5 C] (10/19/2015 11:12) Pulse: 64 (10/19/2015 11:12) Respiration: 18 (10/19/2015 11:12) Blood pressure: 137/80 (10/19/2015 11:12) Weight: 189 lb [85.9 kg] (10/19/2015 11:12) Pain: 0 (10/19/2015 11:12) O2:95 (09/28/2015 10:12) BMI: 26.4 (10/19/2015 11:12) chronically ill appearing, somewhat irritable, disheveled abd nabx, nt, multiple abd hernias noted obxerved stool in bag, is green, thin
LABS
LAST TWO WEEKS LABS ================================================================ AREA 2 Collected: 10/19/2015 11:49 HEMATOLOGY BLOOD WBC - 8.2 RBC - 4.43 HGB - 12.3L HCT - 39.1L MCV - 88.3 MCH - 27.9L MCHC - 31.6L RDW - 17.3H PLT - 363 MPV - 7.9 -------------------- AREA 2 Collected: 10/19/2015 11:49 CHEMISTRY PLASMA GLUCOSE- 74 BUN - 16 CREAT - 1.5 NA - 139 K - 4.4 CL - 103 CO2 - 26 ANI GAP- 14 eGFR - 46L --------------------
ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 1)PRINCIPLE CONCERNS AND MEDICATIONS REVIEWED AND UP-DATED TODAY 2) patient educated about the pertinent aspects of his medical problems and medication side effects today 3) ho rectal ca, sp ostomy placement, noted bloodin ostomy bag hct stable today and stool not melanic of note. spent 2 hours today trying to find out what ostomy suplies the pt needed. his ostomy leaked, and we got clean pants for pt. pt was upset but was able to make it home I put in an ostomy consult no evidence of acute bleeding but put in gi consult also ptwiht ho erosive esophagitis, per him on omeprazole so continued 4) ho cad, on appropriate meds, unclear if taking as he has ho non adherence in past. bp appropriate today 5) deocnditioningh, chornic back pian, poor motivation. offered PT, etc for pt, currently only interested in pain medicaiton. I don't htink he is a good candidate for opioid therapy as he has no functional goals and does not show improvement in funciton with tx. will continue to work with pt. trial tramadol , given other issues today could not address sig so will spend more time next visit.
fu 2 months

SOCIAL WORK NOTE : LOCAL TITLE: SWS - TRIAGE ASSESSMENT STANDARD TITLE: SOCIAL WORK NOTE DATE OF NOTE: SEP 04, 2015@13:42 ENTRY DATE: SEP 04, 2015@13:42:26 AUTHOR: STEYER,JENNIFER A EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** SWS - TRIAGE ASSESSMENT Has ADDENDA ***
SOCIAL WORK TRIAGE ASSESSMENT
Referral source: Other referral source: Providence city136 Hospital ED Social Worker: Karen: 503-513-8320
Presenting issues: Housing
Brief summary: PC Social Worker received a phone call from a ED Social Worker from Providence city136 Hospital stating that Veteran was "kicked out" from an ICF (Pacific Health and Rehab: 503-639-1144) and is now at the ED with a box of his belongings. His ex-wife is not allowing Veteran back into their home, because she cannot care for him.
Is case management recommended? No
Social Work Interventions and Plan: Patient is a 70 year old NSC Vietnam Era Veteran. Veteran receives $1113.00 a month from VA Pension and income from Social Security. Veteran's monthly income is $1700.00 a month. Social Worker reviewed the Veteran's CPRS records and appears that Veteran was discharged from ICF on 09/03/2015 to his ex-wife's home with Home Health follow-up. Does not appear that Veteran was "kicked out" of the facility. Veteran has been involved with APS in the past. Social Worker did contact the Social Worker at Pacific Health and Rehab (Celeste) who stated that Veteran was discharged from the facility, because he refused to pay the facility his liability copay. Veteran is on Medicaid and because of his income he had to pay the facility a certain liability. Veteran owes the facility $4,000-$5,000 which he refused to pay. Celeste advised Social Worker that Veteran does have over $5,000 in his bank account and could have easily paid the facility. Veteran's Medicaid Worker is Kurt Garcia (503-624-4363) who works out of the Tigard DHS Office. Celeste advised this writer that Veteran is able to walk at least 100 feet with his rollator walker, is able to manage his ostomy bag, needs set up to shower, limited assist with putting on clothes (cannot put on his socks), and is able to groom himself. Celeste advised this writer that the Veteran assured the facility that his ex-wife would be able to care for him and that he had a safe d/c plan. Social Worker advised Karen to contact APS and make them aware of Veteran's current situation and that Veteran is now homeless. Social Worker advised Karen that Veteran will not qualify for VA contract placement because he is not Mill Bill eligible. Veteran has the funds to pay for a motel or SRO if needed. Encouraged Karen to call the Veteran's Medicaid worker for further assistance.
Time spent with the veteran for this encounter: 60 minutes.
/es/ Jennifer A Steyer, LCSW, CCM Portland Primary Care Social Worker Signed: 09/04/2015 14:33

LOCAL TITLE: GI - E-CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 21, 2015@12:32 ENTRY DATE: OCT 21, 2015@12:32:12 AUTHOR: COLLINS,JUDITH F EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** GI - E-CONSULT Has ADDENDA ***
Reason For Request: pt with ho rectoal cancer, sp resection/ostomy noted some blood in ostomy bag by report not orthostatic, stool green today hct stable 38(fri), 39 today ostomy area looks pink ho erosive esophagitis admis(on omeprazole) no n/v should his ostomy be scoped?
70 yo male with presumed ileostomy after resection of sigmoid/rectal cancer in 2014. BAsed on my review of the op notes, he had an end to end anastomosis of desc colon to rectal area, and had a postop complication of evisceration. I assume that now he has double barrel ileostomy??? At any rate, I don't know that he needs an urgent eval for bleeding, but would like for the ostomy nurse to look at the stoma for skin irritation, evidence of bleeding at the level of the skin. He is due for a 1 year exam post surgery ; I think he still has colon left. Will ask Dr. Lu to clarify for me.
To perform an exam through his ileostomy, he will need a regular prep and I would suggest enemas x 2 from below. (if possible). He would also benefit from MAC anesthesia since he has pain issues/meds.
/es/ JUDITH F COLLINS, MD STAFF PHYSICIAN Signed: 10/21/2015 12:40
Receipt Acknowledged By: 10/28/2015 12:01 /es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery
10/28/2015 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED Still has colon and part of rectum Double barrelled ileostomy.
/es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery Signed: 10/28/2015 12:02

LOCAL TITLE: COLORECTAL SURG - CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: SURGERY CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 28, 2015@12:00 ENTRY DATE: OCT 28, 2015@12:00:09 AUTHOR: LU,KIM C EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
7- yo obese (BMI 30.2) male with history of colon polyps
HISTORY PRESENT ILLNESS colonoscopy to cecum with excellent prep (4/29/14) 10 mm ascending colon lesion, +pillow sign biopsy: lipoma 8 mm pedunculated descending colon tubular adenoma at 30 cm tattoo proximal 8 mm sigmoid polyp at 22 cm, removed, not retrieved 12 mm rectal lesion at 12 cm from verge tattooed moderately differentiated, focally poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma within a tubular adenoma cancer approximated cauterized margin suspicious for lymphovascular invasion white stippled tissue lateral to base of polyp biopsy: benign
MRI pelvis (6/20/14) T2 lesion at 7 cm from verge N0 no extramural vascular invasion
CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis with oral and iv contrast (5/12/14) "Hypervascular lesions with peripheral enhancement, measuring up to 1.3 cm in diameter within the anterior subcapsular left liver lobe ...and up to 2.0 cm within the posterior liver dome... consistent...with benign liver hemangiomas; these two liver hemangiomas ...unchanged compared with the CT chest with contrast from 7/29/2004" no clear liver or lung metastases
exercise tolerance test (6/26/14) no ECG evidence of ischemia but nuclear part of test showed: "Small region of mild ischemia in the likely distal wrap around LAD, slight progression since 2007
Infarct in the basilar inferior wall likely RCA, unchanged since 2007
Left ventricular ejection fraction is normal with basilar inferior wall akinesis, unchanged since 2007"
seen by cardiology on 9/16/14, no further workup recommended
Continence Flatus: good Stool: good
Bowel Habits: 1 BM/day
Low-anterior resection with tumor-specific mesorectal excision, splenic flexure take-down, 29 EEA stapled end-to-end colorectal anastomosis, resection of umbilical hernia sac and primary repair of umbilical hernia, and construction of a right upper quadrant loop ileostomy (10/3/14) Exploratory laparotomy (for evisceration), placement of 3 external retention sutures, and fascial closure (10/10/14) transferred to CLC on 11/14/14-3/12/15
no show for clinic on 4/22/15 or today
/es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery Signed: 10/28/2015 12:03

WARD PROGRAM: Bed mobility: mod I using bed rails and elevated HOB Out of bed: SBA at rollator in room, w/c for community mobili Wheelchair mobility: mod I
DIAGNOSIS: s/p LAR10/3 and exlap 10/10 2/2 dehiscence
PRECAUTIONS: Falls risk
EQUIPMENT: rollator, SPC, mwc
ANTICIPATED EQUIPMENT NEEDS: none
REASON FOR REFERRAL/HPI: 1) postop 2) Diagnosis: postop LAR, exlap 3) Referral focus: Decline in functional mobility, transfers, gait endurance, etc., Post-Op Care, Assistive Ambulation Devices/ Wheelchairs, etc.
PMHX/PSHX: Delirium (SCT 2776000) Rectal Cancer (ICD-9-CM 154.1) Venous Insufficiency (ICD-9-CM 459.81) Adjustment Disorder (ICD-9-CM 309.9) MUSCLE DISORDERS NEC (ICD-9-CM 728.3) Mood D/O Sec GM Cond (ICD-9-CM 293.83) Hypercholesterolemia (ICD-9-CM 272.0) LBP (ICD-9-CM 724.2) GERD (ICD-9-CM 530.81) Old Myocardial Infarction (ICD-9-CM 412.) Tobacco Use Disorder (ICD-9-CM 305.1) HTN (ICD-9-CM 401.9) PAINFUL RESPIRATION (ICD-9-CM 786.52)
SURGERY LIST 10/10/2014 EXPLORATORY LAPAROTOMY, (COMPLETED) EXPLORATORY CELI 10/03/2014 PROCTECTOMY, PARTIAL RESECTION, (COMPLETED) RECTUM, PROCTECTOMY; PARTIAL RESECTION, RECTUM, TRANSABDOM
PRIOR MOBILITY: Previously, pt lived independently in studio apartment. Primarily uses rollator. At baseline, pt ambulates with forearms on rollator to unload back weight. No stairs to enter. Pt no longer drives. Took taxis to appointments. Used store power scooters for shopping.
D/C LOCATION: It is unlikely pt will be able to return to independent living. Recommend nursing home facility placement.
SUBJECTIVE: "I don't want to do anything. I want to get out of here. This place is stupid. I don't want any therapy." PAIN: not numerically rated. Ambulated with bilateral forearms on rollator to relieve back pain. OBJECTIVE: Pt was very uninterested during conversation. Little to no eye contact. Spoke in whispers barely audible. Appeared agitated with no interest in participating in evaluation or on going therapy.
COGNITION: AO x 3 PATIENT RESPONDED APPROPRIATELY TO 90% OF QUESTIONS AND COMMANDS DURING TODAY'S EVALUATION. Extra time and effort to complete all tasks. Pt appeared to understand commands but was reluctant/resistant to complete or participate.
VITALS: BP: 132/83 (01/09/2015 06:38)61 (01/09/2015 06:38) Pulse: 61 (01/09/2015 06:38) O2 sats: 92 (01/09/2015 06:38)
STRENGTH: R LE L LE Hip flexion 3+/5 3/5 Knee Extension 4/5 3+/5 Knee Flexion 3+/5 3+/5 Dorsiflexion 3+/5 3+/5
RANGE OF MOTION: BLE wfl
BALANCE: Static sit: fair Dynamic sit: fair Static Stand: poor Dynamic Stand: poor
MOBILITY: FIM KEY: 1 dependent; 2 maximum assist; 3 moderate assist; 4 minimum assist; 5 stand by assist; 6 independent w/A.D., or needs additional time, or there is a safety concern; 7 independent
FIM LIST:
Bed Mobility: FIM 6 Transfer - supine to sit: FIM 6 Transfer - sit to stand: FIM 6 Transfer - bed to chair: FIM 6 Locomotion - ambulation: FIM 5 Locomotion - w/c: FIM 1 Locomotion - primary method: Wheelchair Stairs: FIM 1 GAIT DESCRIPTION: Pt amb 50' with SBA using rollator. Pt amb with bilateral forearms on rollator to unweight back. Short, shuffle gait pattern. Despite adequate strength, pt stated he was unable to clear feet bilaterally.
ACTIVITY TOLERANCE: poor RX TODAY (mobility/exercise education): pt educated on role of PT CONTACT/COMMUNICATION w/ OTHER PROVIDERS: Chart review.
EVAL TIME: 30 mins TOTAL TIME: 30 mins
ASSESSMENT: ONE TIME VISIT ONLY. Pt is 69 yo male presenting with deconditioning 2/2 a prolonged and complicated hospital stay. On 10/02/14 pt underwent a low anterior resection (tumor-specific mesorectal excision), construction of a right-sided ileostomy. Excision of an umbilical hernia sac, and primary umbilical hernia repair on 10/03/2014. The patient was doing well until he had more abdominal pain found to have drainage from his incision, and then he eviscerated underwent ex lap on 10/10/14. Pt has spent most of his time in bed since these procedures. Pt is not interested in physical therapy. Pt has a h/o refusals of prior PT attempts and marginally participates in OT. Pt had little/no eye contact during evaluation. Appeared angry and very uninterested. Offered no interest in goal setting. At this time, pt is not appropriate for skilled therapy 2/2 lack of interest and h/o refusals. Pt is more appropriate for restorative nursing for ambulation to/from all meals to maintain current level of function. Recommend Restorative Nursing consult be placed to maintain his current level of function. Pt stated he lives alone and wishes to return to independent living. Pt is not appropriate to return to independent living and is more appropriate for nursing home facility placement. No further PT needs identified. Plan to DC from PT at this time. Please reconsult PT if pt becomes interested in participating in ongoing skilled therapy on a consistent basis.
/es/ JONNI A TANZY Physical Therapist Signed: 01/09/2015 15:33

REASON FOR REFERRAL: Electronic chart and medical/rehab history reviewed. Patient is a 69 yo MALE admitted on NOV 14,2014 12:30 for: 1.) ADMITTING DIAGNOSIS: S/P LAR-EXLAP, WOUND CARE 2.) Rehabilitation due to associated decrease in self-care/IADL.
PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY: (per MD admit note) T2 N0 M0 rectal adenocarcinoma 10/3/2014 Surgical procedure: Low-anterior resection (LAR) End-to-end colorectal anastomosis Loop ileostomy 10/10/2014 Wound dehiscence closed (except inferior aspect) 10/20/2014 Acute altered mental status (delirium?)
OTHER DIAGNOSES TREATED OR IMPACTING TREATMENT THIS ADMISSION: CAD s/p CABG in 2007 Hyperlipidemia Altered Mental Status Malnutrition Deconditioned

STRENGTH - COORDINATION - Grossly functional for managing PJ snaps HEARING: Concerns not noted during eval VISION: Not tested; pt able to read fine print. He stated he did not have glasses, but there were glasses at his bedside VISUAL/PERCEPTUAL DEFICIT: needs further evaluation

ASSESSMENT: Pt is a 69 y.o. Veteran admitted to rehab s/p bowel surgery. He presents with confusion, general deconditioning, below baseline level of self care independence and need for total assist with ostomy management. Per discussion, pt is undecided about whether he plans to return home or if he will seek higher level of care. IADL goals set to reflect level of independence that will be required for pt to return to previous living situation without support, however, it is likely that pt will need a d/c environment where daily assist is available to manage his ostomy care. Anticipate IADL assist, especially med management, may also be indicated s/p discharge pending resolution of symptoms of delirium. Pt would benefit from skilled OT services for assessment of functional cogitation in ADL/IADL context and for maximizing self care independence.
Patient able to participate in, and agreed to goal setting: YES. Patient goal: return home Potential: Good for stated OT goals. Barriers: pt does not think he will feel comfortable managing his own ostomy care Enhancers: Pt was cooperative today
Short Term Goals (date): 1. Don/doff shoes independently/mod I using elastic laces as needed 2. Oriented to year and month consistently. 3. Tolerate being OOB for therapy minimum of 30' for all therapy sessions.
Long Term Goals (date): SELF CARE 1. Dress self independently (mod I) including clothing retrieval. 2. Safely step in/out of shower with grab bar. 3. Groom independently while standing
IADL 1.Demonstrate ability to manage medications based on simulation of filling pill box and coming to med cart on time. 2.Demonstrate independence with simple meal prep. 3.Demo skills required to launder clothing simulating home environment. 4.Demo skills required to grocery shop ( ambulating around store, paying for items, carrying them, putting them away, staying within budget) 5.Demo skills required to perform household chores.
PLAN/RECOMMENDATIONS: OT Treatment 30 minutes , for approx 4 weeks.
Self-Care Training. Activities of Daily Living Training Functional Transfer Training Upper Extremity Therapeutic Exercises Adaptive Equipment Training Cognitive/Perceptual Training
Anticipate discharge to : unknown pending cognition ability/services available to manage ostomy care and IADL Coordination of care: Discuss with team in weekly Interdisciplinary Team Rounds

LOCAL TITLE: PALLIATIVE CARE TEAM - CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: PALLIATIVE CARE CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: NOV 06, 2014@17:43 ENTRY DATE: NOV 06, 2014@17:43:21 AUTHOR: TANNER,CRAIG EDWARD EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
REASON FOR CONSULT: Discussion of goals of care, support for emotional suffering.
PCP: PHYSICIAN-ATTENDING: Carol L Sprague
HPI: Mr. LN136 is a 69 y.o. man with a recent diagnosis of rectal adenocarcinoma, hospitalized since Oct 2 after undergoing resection of his rectum and sigmoid colon. His post-operative course has been complicated by wound dehisence, depression, delirium and hallucinations-pt was on a court hold on teh psychiatry unit earlier in his hospital stay. Now he has been refusing wound care, medications and lab draws. Earlier today the palliative care psychology fellow attempted to engage with pt but pt refused. I approached him later in the afternoon. I asked him about the earlier encounter and he recoutned to me that he was angry that religion was brought up and that he didn't want to talk about that at all. I assured him that there was no need to talk about religion. I then proceeded to ask several questions about his understanding why he was in the hospital. He initially stated "You know that I know why I'm in the hospital". I told him that I am never certain what patients know unless they tell me. He angrily told me to get out of his room and leave him alone. I told him that I would leave later and asked additional questions. I asked him what he was hoping for and he stated "for people to leave me alone and to get well". I told him that I did not think he would be able to get well if he were completely left alone. I asked him what he thought it would take for him to get well. He stated "I don't know, I'm not a doctor". I then explained that the doctors have recommended several things to try to help him to get well and he has been refusing them. He did not respond. I asked him why he thought the doctors were recommending various treatments (medications, wound care, lab draws). He again stated "I don't know, I'm not a doctor". I asked him questions to attempt to assess his cognitive function (starting wtih asking what year it is) and he refused answer, again stating that I knew that he knew this already. I reiterated multiple times that I work with many patients in the hospital who are unable to answer these questions correctly and I am never certain which patients will be able to. He again refused to answer.
I asked if any family had visited him. Her replied that they had not. I asked if he had any close friends/family in the area and he stated he has a daguther and an ex-wife. I asked if they knew that he was here and he stated that he didn't know. I asked if I could call his daugther and he stated "sure, do whatever you want, just leave me alone".
SYMPTOM ASSESSMENT:Not formally assessed. Pt did c/o being very tired multpile times during the interview.
PMH: -RECTAL ADENOCARCINOMA: S/P resection complicated by wound dehisence -CAD -COPD -TOBACCO USE -HTN -HLD -GERD w/intestinal metaplasia (Barrett's esoph) -HX LUMBAR LAMINECTOMY 2001 -HX CHRONIC SINUSITIS
Active Medications: 1) Acetaminophen tab 325-650mg po q4h prn indication: for pain. hold while patient taking vicodin (hydrocodone/acetaminophen) 2) Albuterol inhl,oral 2 puffs inhl oral q4h prn for shortness of breath 3) Albuterol/ipratropium inhl,oral 1 spray inhl oral qid 4) Aluminum/magnesium/simeth susp,oral 1 teaspoonful po q8h prn dyspepsia 5) Aspirin tab,ec 81mg po daily 6) Atorvastatin calcium tab 20mg po qeve 7) Enoxaparin inj 40mg/0.4ml sc qday 8) Haloperidol tab 1mg po bid 9) Hydralazine inj,soln 10mg/0.5ml ivp q2h prn for sbp >170 10) Metoprolol succinate tab,sa 100mg po daily 11) Oxycodone hcl tab 5-15mg po q4h prn for pain. 12) Sodium chloride inj syringe (10 ml) catheter bid flush each port of picc/cvc with 10ml pulsed push technique. (ward stock-accudose) 13) Trazodone tab 100mg po at bedtime for sleep
Allergies: CODEINE, ERYTHROMYCIN, HYDROCODONE
SHX: Marital Status/Family: AS reported in HPI
Military: Service Branch Entered Separated Discharge NAVY DEC 29, 1967 MAY 11, 1970 HONORABLE NAVY AUG 1962 AUG 1966 HONORABLE
Spirituality: Not assessed/discussed today
ADVANCE CARE PLANNING: Decision-making capacity: Unclear Advance Directive: No Code status: Full Code Goals/Values: Unclear. Pt did state that he wants to get well but was unable or unwilling to tell me anything further about what he wants or what might help him to get well.
FUNCTIONAL STATUS: Palliative Performance Scale: Unable to assess today. Has reportedly been walking around the unit at times.
PE: VITALS: Temperature: 98.4 F [36.9 C] (11/05/2014 06:56) Pulse: 92 (11/05/2014 06:56) Respiration: 18 (11/05/2014 06:56) Blood pressure: 135/79 (11/05/2014 06:56) Weight: 189.8 lb [86.3 kg] (11/05/2014 06:56) Pain: 8 (11/06/2014 05:23) O2:91 (11/05/2014 06:56) BMI: 26.5 (11/05/2014 06:56)
GEN: Lying in bed, making no eye contact. Pulm: Breathing not labored at rest Mental Status: Alert, did not answer orientation questions. Poor eye cotnact. Psychomotor retardation noted. Minimal thought content expressed appeared linear. Unable to assess insight/judgement.
LABS/IMAGING: Reviewed
ASSESSMENT: 69 y.o. male with recent resection of rectum & signmoid colon for rectal adenocarcinoma with complicated post-operative course. Pt minimally engatged with me this afternoon. My general impression is that he is not delirious though it is difficult to say given that he would not really engage. I am unable to assess his capacity to make decisions based on today's interview as he was either unable or unwilling to manipulate the information provided and communicate a choice. He certainly has a history of refusing to take medications upon review of his chart from outpatient settings but I am unable to say whether he even understands the interventions/medications being offerred or recommended. Hopefully I will be able to gather more collateral history tomorrow to better assess how we might be able to help Mr. LN136.
PLAN: -Will gather further history tomorrow: --Plan to contact PCP Dr. Sprague --Plan to call pt's daugther -Depending on additional history gathered may need to re-involve psychiatry constul team
Palliative care team will continue to follow.
PATIENT/FAMILY EDUCATION: Discussed with pt need to assess cognitive status and understanding of recommended treatments.

S: Mr. LN136 has had fluctuating delirium believed to be of multifactorial etiology that was mostly improved over the last few days so Haldol (scheduled 1mg BID) was d/ced yesterday morning. Later in the day, pt began reporting that he was seeing "kitties" walking around the room. In discussing this with pt, states he has seen kittens in his room 3 or 4 times and has interacted with them, feeling them as they play with his fingers. Also notes illusions of items on the wall distorting toward him. Still feels safe in the hospital, denying that he feels anyone is coming after him. No SI, HI, AH. He agrees with need to stay in hospital, specifically states that he could not care for himself (particularly his ostomy bag) if he were outside of the hospital. Impression: 69 yo M with fluctuating delirium in setting of complicated post-op recovery (LAR for rectal adenocarcinoma) who developed hallucinations and illusions yesterday in setting of d/ced Haldol. He is indeed still experiencing delirium which is known to have fluctuating course however question if his new hallucinations and illusions are a manifestation of his preexisting delirium revealed due to haldol cessation or if they are due to a new underlying etiology. He had not experienced hallucinations since 10/21 and had not displayed impulsivity or disorientation so his delirium seemed to be resolving as of yesterday morning. This raises concern that his new sxs could be related to a new or worsening underlying cause. Per earlier notes from consult service, head CT may be indicated if sxs do not improve as could have subacute neurologic process. Please monitor for constipation and urinary retention as these are known to precipitate delirium as well. BUN and creatinine are wnl so doubt renal failure as cause. Considered infection though his WBC count has remained normal. Would obtain a UA to r/o UTI. If leukocytosis develops, recommend considering abd etiology with imaging. Anemia has been present and is likely contributing though has not changed so doubt this is causing acute worsening of his delirium. Has had oxycodone which could precipitate delirium however he has been on relatively stable doses so doubt this is contributing to new/worsening process. No new or recently d/ced meds to our knowledge that could be contributing. Should check TSH to evaluate for endocrine etiology. Reporting that his abdomen hurts; pain is also known to precipitate delirium at times. Recent amylase normal but consider repeat if epigastric pain, NV develop. Electrolytes are largely unremarkable, continue to check and replete as necessary. Had normal B12 and Folate earlier this year so unlikely cause. Hypoxia less likely contributing as his O2 sats have been mostly stable. He has significant cardiac hx, most recent troponin and EKG normal but hypoperfusion could cause delirium so should repeat if concern for cardiac event increases. Had normal LFTs so less likely hepatic etiology. Has not had access to substances so unlikely intoxication; he is also past time timeline during which we would expect confusion due to withdrawal. At this time, pt poses little threat of elopement as he seems to be experiencing more of a hypoactive delirium. However, in anticipating potential development of this threat as occurred when he first became delirious on 10/20, would recommend reinitiating Haldol at scheduled dose as he was on until yesterday. Would encourage supportive environment including frequent reorientation, limiting lines and exposure to light during the daytime. Also recommend therapeutic companion at nursing discretion, orange pajamas to alert staff, have low threshold for capacity assessment if pt threatens to leave. Thank you for requesting our continued involvement in Mr. LN136's care, we will continue to follow.
Recommendations: -Haldol 1mg PO tonight then scheduled Haldol 1mg PO BID -Pursue aggressive workup for potential causes of new/worsening delirium (UA, TSH in addition to LFTs, CBC and CMP which you have already been checking) -Head CT if pt does not improve with Haldol -Therapeutic companion at nursing discretion -Low threshold for capacity assessment if elopment risk develops -Psychiatry will continue to follow
Patient discussed with my supervising practitioner and C/L attending Dr. Stacey Gramann, who is in agreement with the assessment and plan.

Impression: Mr. LN136 is a 69 year old male veteran who has had fluctuating mental status 2/2 delirium in setting of complicated post-op recovery who again developed hallucinations and illusions 10/24 after haloperidol was d/c'd. Today, unable to fully assess Mr. LN136 given irritability and lack of compliance with interview. He is oriented and not hallucinating during our visit however has well-documented fluctuating sxs over the last two days consistent with diagnosis of delirium. Delirium likely of multifactorial etiology, may have underlying neurocognitive disorder contributing. Appropriate workup has been initiated with findings of anemia and hypomagnesemia. Note pt has also been hypoxic which, when combined with anemia, could be causing delirium due to decreased oxygen delivery to his brain. Recommend supplemental O2 if pt remains hypoxic. Still could benenfit from UA to r/o UTI as additional contributing factor. At this time would recommend continuation of Haldol 1mg PO BID, could supplement this PRN agitation. As haldol increases risk for prolonged QT, should obtain repeat EKG, monitor Mg and K and replete as needed. When anticipating d/c, would be best to try to taper Haldol. However, if seems unsafe to do so with agitation and continued delirium could continue Haldol with close outpatient mental health f/u. Mr. LN136 has repeatedly stated that he plans to stay in the hospital for the sake of his health, though could pose an elopement risk particularly as he is resistant to plan for feeding tube. Should primary team have increasing concern for elopement risk, capacity assessment would be indicated. At this time, does not pose an imminenet threat to self or others. Psychiatry team to sign off. Thank you for requesting our involvement in Mr. LN136's care, please do not hesitate to contact us with further questions.
Recommendations: -Continue haloperidol 1mg PO BID with 0.5 mg PO or 0.25mg IV q4h PRN agitation (not to exceed 4mg total per day) -When aprroaching d/c, attempt to taper Haldol. If need for Haldol remains (i.e. continued delirium and agitation), could continue this but will require close mental health followup as an outpatient. -Due to risk of prolonged QT, order EKG, follow Mg and K while on Haldol -Continue workup for potential causes of new/worsening delirium - still need UA -Therapeutic companion at nursing discretion -Continue behavioral interventions including frequent reorientation, reassurance, light exposure during day. -Low threshold for capacity assessment if elopment risk develops -Psychiatry will sign off at this time.

There is a therapeutic companion in the room who states that he has appeared sleepy and has occasionally shouted out random things. He denies any auditory or visual hallucinations today. He states that he has had hallucinations in the past when he has "put himself in the position to" but that he is not put in that position now. He was unable to clarify what position this might be. He also denied any hallucinations regarding cats/kittens. He feels that he didn't sleep well last night, and endorses being sleepy today.

MSE: General appearance: 69 yo M appears stated age, somewhat disheveled grooming and in hospital PJs. Behavior and psychomotor activity: cooperative, sedate. He has his eyes closed through most of today's exam. Language and speech: Speech slurred,comprehensible; reduced rate and monotone. Thought Process: Linear Content: Denied AVH, SI, HI Mood: "Depends on which games are playing" (re: NFL on TV) Affect: Sleepy Judgment: Fair. Choosing to stay in hospital for sake of his health. Insight: Questionable. Unable to state why he is in the hospital today. Cognition: Small error on date (felt it was 24 Oct 2014) otherwise oriented. WORLD backward = DLRO and then neglected to say the W. Similarly, serial 3's 20-17-14-11-8 then could not continue. Some attentional deficit, possibly too sleepy. Impression: Mr. LN136 is a 69 year old male veteran who has had fluctuating mental status 2/2 delirium in setting of complicated post-op recovery who again developed hallucinations and illusions 10/24 after haloperidol was d/c'd. Mr. LN136 is mostly oriented today, felt it was the 24th but did know it was Sunday (possibly from cues from NFL on TV). Per his nurse and therapeutic companion, he has been oriented and exhibited no impulsivity or behavioral dyscontrol, though has been reported that he has called out which may be 2/2 hallucinations or dreams. He does appear fatigued, and exhibits some attentional deficit that was not there per prior notes. He may be experiencing a hypoactive state in his delirium. He also received 10mg oxycodone approximately 4 hours before, and haloperidol two hours before, which may be contributing to sedation.
Overall, Mr. LN136 seems to have responded well to reinitiation of haloperidol. He is oriented to month/year, place, person and he is no longer reporting any hallucinations. He continues to be a low risk of elopement in his current hypoactive state.
There are no signs of rigidity, dyskinesia, akathisia on exam today.
Thank you for requesting our continued involvement in Mr. LN136's care, we will continue to follow.

Impression: 69 year old MALE with hx of depression and antisocial personality d/o in hospital s/p LAR for rectal adenocarcinoma 10/3 with complicated post-op course who developed acute delirium 10/20, was transferred to 5C and currently on court hold. Delirium continues to fluctuate but is overall improved as evidenced by staff reports and improved interaction and cognition on exam today. Etiology of his delirium is likely multifactorial with most likely contributing factors being renal insufficiency, urinary retention, constipation, hypoxia, anemia, pain, possible infection. Most other causes of delirium have been adequately assessed though if delirium persists, would recommend head CT to evaluate for acute neuro changes as another possible etiology. Notably, pt may have underlying mild neurocognitive d/o that predisposes him to delirium. Recommed this be further evaluated as an outpt after delirium resolution. In reviewing chart, pt has been irritable but has not threatened to leave hospital since onset of his delirium 3 nights ago. He has appropriate insight regarding need to stay in hospital at the recommendation of his primary team. Thus, feel court hold no longer necessary and that transfer to 9th floor with continued therapeutic companion is reasonable at this time. Recommend that primary team maintain scheduled haldol at current dose (QTc, K and Mg all wnl; continue to monitor) given steady regression of sxs. Appreciate staff attention to and documentation of delirious sxs, we will continue to follow.
Recommendations: -Transfer to 9th floor is reasonable -Recommend continue therapeutic companion -Continue scheduled Haldol PO 1mg BID with EKG, K+ and Mg++ daily while on this medication. -Staff to document s/s of delirium -If delirium persists or worsens, obtain head CT to r/o acute neuro changes as possible etiology -Psychiatry will continue to follow

Assessment: Mr. LN136 is a 69 yo M with hx of CAD s/p 3v CABG who is POD#18 s/p Lower Anterior Resection for rectal adenocarcinoma now on court hold after developing AMS with impulsivity last night most c/w a delirious episode. Has had visual hallucinations, now resolved, as well as fluctuating cognition which support dx of delirium. Biologically, is admitted with medical complications that could be contributing to delirium. Had a recent infection (presumed abdominal) which was treated with Zosyn, clean UA and WBC returned to normal today however could still have underlying infection with ostomy being potential route. Asterixis on exam is reassuring that this is likely due to an acute medical condition as opposed to a chronic neurocognitive disorder; should check LFT and ammonia to assess. Electrolytes with slightly elevated BUN/Creatinine suggesting AKI as a potential etiology. Electrolytes o/w unremarkable. Had normal B12 and Folate earlier this year however will need to check TSH, RPR, HIV and Vitamin D in order to more fully evaluate for medical causes. He is on a nasal cannula inconsistently and had ABG with low pO2 so hypoxia may be contributing factor. Reporting that his abdomen hurts, pain is also known to precipitate delirium at times. Also consider pancreatitis with amylase and lipase. He has significant cardiac hx with recent CP concerning for MI, troponin and EKG normal so this is less likely the cause of his AMS. Psychologically, has underlying mild cognitive impairment per chart review which place him at higher risk of delirium. Socially is at risk for delirium as he has been displaced from his regular environment during this prolonged hospital stay. As delirium is a fluctuating process that frequently worsens at night, concerned for pt's safety and will need to maintain on court hold here with 1:1 supervision overnight. Filed new court hold form. Given stability after 3mg Haldol today, recommend scheduled doses tonight, tomorrow morning and tomorrow at noon. Request that staff document delirious sxs overnight. Psychiatry team will reassess tomorrow for immediate concerns (hallucinations, SI, HI, medication side effects) tomorrow and plan for outpt f/u to assess for cognitive impairment once delirium has resolved and is medically stable for d/c.
Recommendations: -Haldol 2.5mg Qpm, 1mg at 0800 and 1 mg at noon -Check repeat EKG, follow K+ and Mg++ while on Haldol -LFTs, Ammonia, Amylase, Lipase r/o other possible delirium etiologies -Is an elopement risk, maintain 1:1 RN care on 5C tonight -Repeat assessment tomorrow to assess for SI, HI, medication side effects -Will place referral for outpt Geri Psych f/u to assess cognitive impairment
Diagnosis: Delirium Unspecified Neurocognitive Disorder

10/21/2014 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED Patient seen with MS3 Beth Krautschied and supervision provided. Briefly, Mr. LN136 is a 69 year old male with past psychiatric history notable for depressive symptoms and unclear prior cognitive impairment, now admitted for rectal surgery for CA diagnosis. This procedure complicated by wound dehiescience, later chest pain, and finally agitation with demands to discharge from the hospital with episodes of pulling at surgical lines. He was transferred to the med/psych bed on 5c, placed on NMI hold, and treated with total of 3 mg haldol over 16 hours. Since that time, reports from nursing staff indicate that he has been somewhat more calm, although refusing medications at times. Psychiatry service consulted for recommendations regarding investigation of causes of delirium, as well as medication recommendations on how to manage episodic agitation.
On my exam, patient is 69 year old male who appears stated age, dressed in hospital clothes. Initially sleeping, but awakes to loud voice and gentle tap on leg. Generally cooperative with exam, though at times declines to participate in mental status exam. Speech normal rate, rhythm, tone and volume. Thought process mostly logical and goal-directed, though at times diverges onto tangents which are not always clear to interviewers. Thought content notable for reports of possible visual hallucinations over past 24 hours, though none notable on this exam. No SI/HI. Mood is fair, affect vaguely anxious. Cognition grossly impaired; notable for limited orientation to time (October, does not know year/date). Formal testing not completed at this time. Insight fair, judgment limited.
At this time, presentation most consistent with delirium. Possible additional component of underlying dementia, though lack of clear baseline cognitive assessment makes this hard to clarify. Recent agitation makes for difficult treatment of medical conditions. Given this, would agree with ongoing NMI.
Completed NMI form again, given concerns from MC ICP, per GS team report. Would also recommend standing haldol: 1 mg daily at 8am and noon, 2.5 mg qHS. Continue to monitor EKG (for QTc prolongation) and K, Mg. Continue to work up causes of delirium - would agree with possible abdominal CT, would also recommend LFTs, ammonia, lipase, amylase.
Psychiatry consult service will continue to follow. This case discussed with, and patient seen with, Todd Eisenberg, attending psychiatrist, who agrees with the above assessment and plan.
/es/ John C. Wilson, MD, PhD Fellow, Geriatric Psychiatry Signed: 10/21/2014 20:31

LOCAL TITLE: MHD - INPAT - PSYCHIATRY CONSULT STANDARD TITLE: PSYCHIATRY CONSULT DATE OF NOTE: OCT 21, 2014@17:30 ENTRY DATE: OCT 21, 2014@21:08:08 AUTHOR: EISENBERG,TODD D EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Psychiatry Staff
Asked by surgery service to evaluate Veteran for assessment and management of confusion, agitation, psychotic sx's. Reviewed chart. Evaluated Veteran c geriatric psychiatry fellow Dr. Wilson -- please see his note dated today for full details of hpi, past hx, social hx, labs/tests.
In brief, this is a 69y/o male c psychiatric hx notable for past dx of antisocial personality d/o (dx made during inpatient psychiatric hospitalization in 1995, but records from that admission not immediately available, so do not know rationale for that dx), depression (dx of mdd v mood d/o secondary to CAD), delirium (during 2006 admission for ARF and rhabdo), and ?baseline cognitive deficits (although we could not locate any formal cognitive exams, there was a suspicion of a "mild cognitive disorder" in previous outpatient psychiatric evaluations.
Now, he is admitted to the surgical service for LAR c diverting ileostomy for a rectosigmoid adenocarcinoma (currently POD#18). Post-op course c/b fascial dehiscence necessitating ex-lap and repair; sepsis; hypoxia, oliguria.
Last noc, Veteran appeared to be at baseline during evening shift (per nursing notes). Then, at 11PM, he exhibited psychotic sx's (hallucinosis of soldiers, children, and police; persecutory delusions that nurse had a gun, that his life was in danger), agitation, and confusion (disoriented, fluctuating mental status). He received 25mg of quetiapine last noc, 2mg IV haldol at 0948 and 1mg IV haldol at 1130. Fluctuation of level of arousal/confusional sx's persists and Veteran has been pulling at ostomy site and IV.
Veteran has a limited recall of events of last noc and today. However, he does acknowledge confusion and suspects he was hallucinating.
Vitals: 97.8 HR 76 BP 148/83 R 20 Wt 199.6 lbs MSE: Lying in bed in johnnie. Initially asleep and roused to loud voice. Initially quite confused but thought process/clarity improved after several minutes of discussion. Speech normal rate, volume, tone. Thought initially confused with tangential/disconnected answers to questions, but after ~5 minutes thought was fairly linear and goal-directed. Believes he likely had VH's last noc. Denies ah/oh. No overt delusions currently. Affect initially irritable, but euthymic after able to develop rapport. No si voiced. COGNITIVE: Initially drowsy but arousable. After 5 minutes fully aroused. Oriented to October 9th (rather than 21st) and did not know year. Initially did not know where he was or why he was here. After clearing somewhat remembered that he had rectal CA and surgical rsxn/ Language fluent c comprehension grossly intact. No paraphasic errors. Attn: Max digit span forward 5; bkwds 3. DOWB intact. Cognitive exam limited by Veteran's reluctance to engage in what he thought were "games".
PE: Minimal rigidity of LUE>RUE. Mild/mod resting tremor and +asterixis. CN 2-12 intact except for poor visual acuity. Sensory UE & LE's grossly intact to LT. Motor 5/5 UE's; did not test LE's due to pain from surgery. Cerebellar RAM intact. DTR: Brachioradialis 2+ bilateral & symmetric.
Imp: 69y/o male c psychiatric hx notable for historical dx of depression and antisocial personality d/o. Also with h/o possible baseline cognitive deficits and with clear h/o delirium. Now, in context of recovery from LAR c diverting ileostomy for rectosigmoid andenocarcinoma with a complicated post-op course, Veteran clearly exhibited sx's c/w delirium (agitation, psychosis, confusion) last noc and today. 2/3 of individuals c delirium have underlying dementia -- thus, he is at some risk for having dementia despite our being unable to adequately evaluate for possible dementia in context of resolving delirium. For now, would continue to w/u potential medical causes of delirium as you are doing. Would work to avoid subsequent acute exacerbations of agitated delirium by converting to standing haloperidol regimen (may keep PRN's, but preferable to "stay ahead" of delirium with standing dose).
Plan: 1) Add'l delirium lab w/u: LFT's, ammonia, amylase, lipase (agree with your plan for abdominal CT) 2) Dementia lab w/u (although not emergently needed, would be helpful to get in-house as there are a number of potentially reversible causes of baseline cognitive deficits/dementia that are yet to be ruled out): TSH, RPR, HIV, Vitamin D 3) Repeat EKG to look for QT prolongation. 4) STANDING Haloperidol 1mg IV @ 0800 & 1200. Haloperidol 2.5mg IV qHS Will adjust standing dose based on response. If requiring PRN's, will add amount required in PRN's to standing regimen. If delirium improves, will start to taper. 5) Agree c med-psych bed for now. Will continue to follow c you.
/es/ TODD D EISENBERG MD STAFF PSYCHIATRIST Signed: 10/21/2014 21:46

ASSESSMENT: 69 y/o male POD 3 s/p rom LAR on 10/3/14. patient is irritable and appears discouraged. Decreased cooperation. Required min (a) supine to sit. Declines to learn use of most of the equipment OT offered to help him adhere to abdominal precautions. Sleeps on a mattress on the floor at home which will make adhering to abdominal precautions unlikely. Patient can benefit from continued acute OT services and he does agree to SNF rehab stay.
Pt ABLE TO PARTICIPATE IN AND AGREED TO GOAL SETTING: yes Pt GOAL: eat breakfast REHAB POTENTIAL: good when he agrees to participate Barriers: irritability Enhancers: VA resources STG date: log roll supine to sit: independent log roll sit to supine: independent sit to stand with rollator walker: SBA ambulates to/from bathroom with walker: SBA dons and removes socks with AD: independent dons and removes pants with AD: independent verbalizes understanding of use of LH bath sponge: Y/N Dons/doffs socks with AD: independent by 10-30-14 LTG date: patient will participate in ADL/mobility task performance independently and without LOB within 2 weeks from this evaluation date.
PLAN: OT to see 1 X week to address the above goals. MD may wish to consider Psych consult to eval for r/o depression vs personality style as barrier to participation.
EQUIPMENTS NEEDS: OT provided a reacher today. Will provide other needed equipment for ADL performance at SNF, if patient agrees to attempt use of equipment. D/C RECOMMENDATIONS: SNF level rehab X 2 weeks with OT to see 6 X week for ADL and IADLs compensatory strategy training. Patient agrees to go. COORDINATION OF CARE: nursing
PLAN OF CARE: ADLS retraining and/or compensatory strategies, education r/t precautions, transfer training, ambulation r/t self care performance, adaptive equipment needs addressed, discharge planning needs addressed.
This note is to serve as a discharge summary if no additional occupational therapy services are provided or patient discharges from the hospital prior to an additional therapy visit.
/es/ MARYALICE BURTON, MS, OT/L Occupational Therapist Signed: 10/08/2014 08:48

DISCHARGE SUMMARY : LOCAL TITLE: Discharge Summary STANDARD TITLE: DISCHARGE SUMMARY DICT DATE: MAR 13, 2015@10:29 ENTRY DATE: MAR 13, 2015@10:30:03 DICTATED BY: LAYNE,RICHARD D ATTENDING: LAYNE,RICHARD D URGENCY: routine STATUS: COMPLETED
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Richard Layne MD AGSF FACP
PHYSICIAN-ATTENDING: Carol L Sprague
PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS: Ileostomy
OTHER DIAGNOSES TREATED OR IMPACTING TREATMENT THIS ADMISSION: Please see summary below.
SUMMARY: (ABBREVIATED HPI, PE, AND PERTINENT LABS) EVENTS LEADING TO CLC ADMISSION 10/3 PVAMC: Low-anterior resection (LAR) for rectal ca, with end-to-end colorectal anastomosis, and loop ileostomy; postop wound dehiscence; delirium; consultation by Psychiatry; studies noncontrib.; haloperidol added 10/10 Closure of abdominal wound dehiscence (except inferior aspect)
REASON FOR CLC ADMISSION For PT and OT and ostomy care training
HOSPITAL COURSE: CLC course overall: his abdominal wound healed and some residual effects of PVAMC-related delirium resolved. Evidence emerged of his underlying antisocial personality disorder including threatening staff and angry-sounding terse responses. Although these tendencies improved he removed highly resistant to learning his ostomy care. This presented a serious barrier to discharge despite efforts of the entire team including psychiatry. During th entire CLC stay he spent a very large percentage of his time in bed; indeed, essentially the only time that he elected to be out of bed was to for toileting and to smoke.
He was presented with a discharge date of the day after his Surgery clinic appointment; with this, he actually began participating somewhat more in learning his ostomy care and demonstrated ability to empty his bag. He was offered and encouraged to go on pass as a trial but he refused.
Home health was arranged with agreement to see him day after discharge.
---BY PROBLEM--- ================================================================================ Problem List -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- REHABILITATION RELATED # Rehab needs including needed self-care of new ostomy 12/5 OT: better participation; MOCA 20/30 12/10 NB: Per surgeon, Dr. Lu: RTC Dr Lu in 3 mo. for eval for poss. takedown 12/24 Barrier: insufficient participation in learning self-care of ostomy 1/21/15 Barrier: same; progress on this remains stalled 2/2015 See OT notes
WOUNDS, LINES, OSTOMIES # Wound care Site Abdominal Type Dehiscence of incision Stage na 12/4 Improved 12/10 Improved Eschar removed by Surgery at clinic with advice: leave open to air 12/17 Essentially healed
NEOPLASTIC DISEASE # T2 N0 M0 rectal adenocarcinoma 10/3/14 Low-anterior resection (LAR) for rectal ca, with end-to-end colorectal anastomosis, and loop ileostomy
CARDIOVASCULAR # CAD s/p CABG in 2007 ... Continue metoprolol 12/4 Resume atorvastatin
# H/o Hyperlipidemia
PULMONARY # COPD CT chest 2014: "Moderate centrilobular emphysema, upper lobe-predominant" - albuterol INH PRN
GI/NUTRITION # GERD (by his hx) 12/11 Added rantidine 12/17 Switch to omeprazole (his reported home med) 1/20 Offered additional med (for nausea) - he declined
NEUROPSYCH # Mental health: h/o depression and antisocial personality disorder 10/20 Acute altered mental status (delirium?) at PVAMC 10/21 Haloperidol begun and continued at 1 mg BID mostly 11/14 Haloperidol stopped 11/18 Haloperidol resumed at 1 mg BID for paranoia with psychotic elements along with threatening staff and interfering with our provision of his care 12/4 Improved Reduce haloperidol to 0.5 mg q am and 1.0 mg q HS Continue trazodone 12/11 Continued improvement 12/17 Recent mild threat (raised arm); aggressive propensity less with males Depressive symptoms Changed trazodone to PRN 12/27 Report of combined auditory and visual hallucinations (see note) 1/12 Last dose tapered haloperidol. Been using PRN trazodone HS each day. 1/13 Reduced dose of PRN trazodone to 50 mg for 1 week with order to dc then. 1/20 Offered antidepressant med - he declined 2/17 Globally improved. Carried on normal conversation with insight and humor. Still remained in bed most of time and did not participate much in learning ostomy care.
# CNCP Syndrome: Chronic low back pain (by his hx prior use of morphine and methadone for this) 12/17 Reduce PRN oxycodone 5-10 mg q 4h (mostly using 10 and >4h) to 5 mg q 6h 1/3/15 DC'd PRN oxycodone
FUNCTIONAL STATUS: (MAY INCLUDE ACTIVITY LEVEL, WORK RESTRICTIONS, OR DIET) Independent in mobility. See above.
DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: ALBUTEROL 90MCG (CFC-F) 200D ORAL INHL USE 2 PUFFS BY MOUTH EVERY 4 HOURS AS NEEDED FOR BREATHING (EACH ASPIRIN 81MG EC TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY ATORVASTATIN CALCIUM 20MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY EVENING TO LOWER CHOLESTEROL AVOID METOPROLOL TARTRATE 25MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH TWICE A DAY NITROGLYCERIN 0.4MG SL TAB DISSOLVE ONE TABLET UNDER THE TONGUE AS NEEDED FOR CHEST PAIN-IF NO
CLINICAL ISSUES REQUIRING FOLLOW UP DURING PC PHONE APT: 1. Ostomy care.
ADDITIONAL FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: Future Appointments: 06/03/15 10:30 EYE NEURO-8C Also, he was seen in Surgery clinic 3/11/15 and this was in note: "He will come back to see Dr. Lu at about 6 mo from daf operation so sometime in April to discuss possibility of takedown pending improved nutrition"
/es/ Richard D. Layne MD Staff Attending; CLC Medical Director Signed: 03/13/2015 11:07

DISCHARGE SUMMARY : LOCAL TITLE: Discharge Summary STANDARD TITLE: DISCHARGE SUMMARY DICT DATE: NOV 14, 2014@11:02 ENTRY DATE: NOV 14, 2014@11:02:45 DICTATED BY: BEHRENS,BRANDON JAM ATTENDING: LU,KIM C URGENCY: routine STATUS: COMPLETED
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Kim C. Lu, MD
PRIMARY CARE PROVIDER AND FACILIITY: Sprague,Carol L || PHONE:55596 || PAGER:503-250-5571
PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. mri T2 N0 M0 rectal adenocarcinoma at 11.5 cm from the anal verge, status post polypectomy with a positive margin.
OTHER DIAGNOSES TREATED OR IMPACTING TREATMENT THIS ADMISSION: 1. History of CAD s/p CABG in 2007 2. Hyperlipidemia 3. Altered Mental Status 4. Malnutrition
PROCEDURES PERFORMED AT THIS HOSPITAL DURING CURRENT ADMISSION:
PROCEDURE PERFORMED on 10/03/2014: 1. Low-anterior resection with tumor-specific mesorectal excision. 2. Splenic flexure take-down. 3. 29 EEA stapled end-to-end colorectal anastomosis. 4. Flexible sigmoidoscopy. 5. Placement of a #19 Blake drain through the left lower quadrant abdominal wall and into the presacral space. 6. Resection of umbilical hernia sac and primary repair of umbilical hernia. 7. Construction of a right upper quadrant loop ileostomy.
PROCEDURE PERFORMED on 10/10/2014: 1. Exploratory laparotomy. 2. Placement of 3 external retention sutures. 3. Fascial closure.
SUMMARY: Clinical History taken from operative report indications by Dr. Lu on 10/03/2014:
"Patient is a 69-year-old, obese male with a history of colon polyps. He underwent a surveillance colonoscopy to the cecum with an excellent prep on April 29, 2014. That found a 10 mm ascending colon lipoma. There was an 8 mm pedunculated descending colon tubular adenoma at 30 cm. That was removed. The tattoo was placed proximally. There was an 8 mm sigmoid polyp at 22 cm that was removed but not retrieved. There was a 12 mm rectal lesion at 12 cm from the anal verge; that was removed. Pathology found a moderately differentiated, focally poorly differentiated, adenocarcinoma within a tubular adenoma with a positive margin. This was positive for lymphovasccular invasion. This had been tattooed adjacent to the polyp. There was a white stippled lesion lateral to the base of the polyp. Biopsy was benign.
Staging MRI of the pelvis on June 20, 2014 found a T2 lesion at 7 cm from the anal verge. N0. There was no extramural vascular invasion. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with oral and IV contrast on May 12, 2014 found a 1.3 cm hypervascular lesion within the left liver lobe. There was a 2 cm lesion of the posterior liver dome. Those was consistent with benign liver hemangiomas and have been unchanged from a prior examination on July 29, 2004. There are no clear liver or lung metastases.
AT this point, I saw the patient and performed a rigid proctoscopy on September 10, 2014. I found tattoo but no lesion at 11.5 cm from the anal verge. Hence, he has at least an mri T2 N 0M0 malignant polyp at approximately 11.5 cm from the anal verge.
I offered a low anterior resection. He needed to be cleared by Cardiology who saw him on September 16, 2014. They felt no further workup was recommended; however, they did recommend that he take his prescribed medications including his Metoprolol, aspirin, and lisinopril.
Patient was admitted yesterday. He underwent an oral antibiotic and mechanical bowel prep. He comes today for the above procedure."
HOSPITAL COURSE: 1. Rectal Cancer s/p LAR with loop ileostomy on 10/03: Mr. LN136 was taken to the operating room on 10/03 for the aforementioned procedures, tolerated the operation well, had no apparent complications, had an uneventful recovery from anesthetic, and was transferred to the ward for routine postoperative care. His initial postopertive course was uncomplicated and progressed his diet, return of bowel function, ilesotomy output, and wound healing appropriately. However, on POD#7 he developed acute abdominal pain, clear drainage from his midline incision, and eviscerated on the floor. He was taken urgently to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy with fascial closure. Postoperatively he was unable to wean off of mechanical ventilation and was requiring pressor therapy to maintain his postoperative blood pressures so he was transferred to the ICU. Pressors were discontinued upon arrival to the ICU and both mechanical ventilation and tube feeds were discontinued on POD#2 s/p exlap and closure. Due to the nature of his case and the presence of leukocytosis on routine postop labs, he had a 7 day course of IV zosyn but was never septic and never developed an intraabdominal infection. He was transferred out of the unit 3 days after his fascial closure and continued to have an uncomplicated recovery from a surgical standpoint. His ostomy output quickly stabilized and his wound was left to heal by secondary intention with BID wet to dry dressing changes.
2. History of CAD s/p CABG in 2007: Mr. LN136 underwent a preop cardioloy evaluation and was cleared for surgery. He had no intraoperative cardiopulmonary complications and was started on his home doses of ASA, metoprolol, and simvastatin on POD#1. He continued to do well from a cardiac standpoint until his dehiscence and second operation at which time he was found to have troponinemia. Cardiology was consulted and felt that his troponinemia represented a Type 2 NSTEMI secondary to demand ischemia postoperatively and their only recommendations were to increase his daily dose of simvastatin. Additionally, on POD#8 from his second procedure he was transferred to the ICU overnight for chest pain (all workup was negative) and cardiology was reconsulted and recomended increasing his metoprolol dose. After this episode, he has had no additional episodes of chest pain on no additional aberrancies in his cardiac markers.
3. Nutrition: Following his procedures, Mr. LN136 was slow to increase his po intake and advance his diet with low serum prealbumin levels. Nutrition was consulted and recommended the following: regular diet, TID protein/high calorie dietary supplements, and double portions on all meals with calorie counts. By November 11th, his prealbumin level was within normal limits at > 23 and he was meeting caloric requirements with his regimen of supplements and double portions.
4. Psychiatry: Following his second operation, on 10/20/2014 Mr. LN136's mental status became acutely altered, he became increasingly agitated and evasive, and he began to refuse all of his cares. Psychiatry was consulted and he was transferred to the psychiatric ward under a 2 physician hold where he remained until 10/23. Overall assessment has been that he is simply evasive and unwilling to participate in interviewing so an official assessment of his decision making capacity was never performed. Following his episode of acute altered mental status, he was placed on a tapering regimen of haloperidol which he will not be discharged on. After returning to the general surgery ward, he continued to be reticent and somewhat evasive, however, he generally became more compliant with his cares and postoperative care. Of note, he did refuse evaluation by the inpatient physical therapy service prior to hospitalization and was discharged from their service before they were able to make recommendations.
FUNCTIONAL STATUS:
Activity: No PT recommendations. However, no activity restrictions from a surgical standpoint. Should wear an abdominal binder for comfort.
Lifting: No hard lifting restrictions at this time as he is already more than 4 weeks out from his most recent fascial closure.
Nutrition: Recommend continuing regular diet, TID protein/calorie supplement shakes, and calorie counts.
Ostomy: Well managed with stable output. Has received all appropriate teaching.
Wound: Inferior aspect of midline laparotomy incision healing by secondary intent. Currently dressing with an ABD and securing in place with an abdominal binder.
DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Active and Recently Expired Outpatient Medications (excluding Supplies):
Active Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) ALBUTEROL 100/IPRATRO 20MCG 120D PO INHL USE 1 SPRAY ACTIVE BY MOUTH FOUR TIMES A DAY 2) ASPIRIN 81MG EC TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY ACTIVE DAY 3) ATORVASTATIN CALCIUM 20MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY ACTIVE MOUTH EVERY EVENING TO LOWER CHOLESTEROL *AVOID GRAPEFRUIT PRODUCTS WITH THIS MEDICINE 4) LISINOPRIL 10MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY ACTIVE DAY FOR BLOOD PRESSURE 5) NITROGLYCERIN 0.4MG SL TAB DISSOLVE ONE TABLET UNDER ACTIVE THE TONGUE MAY REPEAT EVERY 5 MINUTES AS NEEDED FOR CHEST PAIN-IF NO RELIEF AFTER FIRST TABLET CALL 911 6) TRAZODONE HCL 100MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH AT ACTIVE BEDTIME
Pending Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) ALBUTEROL INHL,ORAL USE 2 PUFFS BY MOUTH EVERY 4 PENDING HOURS AS NEEDED FOR SHORTNESS OF BREATH 2) METOPROLOL SUCCINATE 100MG SA TAB TAKE ONE-HALF PENDING TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY FOR HEART FAILURE
Inactive Outpatient Medications Status ========================================================================= 1) MINERAL OIL ENEMA INSTILL 1 CONTENTS INTO RECTUM ONCE EXPIRED AS DIRECTED 2 HOURS BEFORE APPOINTMENT WITH DR. LU ON AUGUST 27, 2014 2) POLYETHYLENE GLYCOL 3350 PWDR,ORAL MIX AS DIRECTED IN EXPIRED WATER OR JUICE AND DRINK AS DIRECTED FOR PROCEDURE
10 Total Medications HDRM - Remote Active Meds
No Active Remote Medications for this patient
RART - Remote ADR
No Remote Allergy/ADR Data available for this patient
MEDICATIONS THAT HAVE BEEN DISCONTINUED: None
CLINICAL ISSUES REQUIRING FOLLOW UP DURING PC PHONE APT: 1. Ostomy output 2. PO intake and nutritional status 3. Status of abdominal wound 4. Participation with staff and self-cares
ADDITIONAL FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: SPECIALTY EXPECTED DATE SCHEDULED(Y/N) POINT OF CONTACT 1. General Surgery 1 month Requested 2. 3.
FOLLOW UP LABS INCLUDING PATHOLOGY & MICROBIOLOGY: TEST ORDERED(Y/N) EXPECTED DATE IF NOT ORDERED
None. No pending labs and all final pathology has been reported.
FOLLOW UP IMAGING AND PROCEDURES: PROCEDURE ORDERED(Y/N) EXPECTED DATE IF NOT ORDERED
None.
/es/ BRANDON JAMES BEHRENS MD Resident | General Surgery Signed: 11/14/2014 12:23
/es/ Kim C. Lu, MD Colon and Rectal Surgery Cosigned: 11/17/2014 16:24

LN136,FN136 MN136 SSN136 DOB-DOB136 M Exm Date: OCT 11, 2014@14:24 Req Phys: BOMMIASAMY,ARAVIND KUMAR Pat Loc: OP Unknown/11-04-2015@11:43 Img Loc: CAT SCAN-X Service: OPERATIVE CARE
(Case 2689 COMPLETE) CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS, W/O CONTRAST (CT Detailed) CPT:74176 Reason for Study: PODE1 abdominal washout ex-lap for fascial dehisence
Clinical History: POD#8 LAR with loop ileostomy, had fascial dehisence yesterday now POD#1 ex-lap fascial closure. Elevated WBC today evaluating for intraabdominal infectious source
Report Status: Verified Date Reported: OCT 12, 2014 Date Verified: OCT 12, 2014 Verifier E-Sig:/ES/NORA DOBOS
Report: Estimated Dose:
Total mAs: 1580
CTDI vol (mGy): 37
DLP (mGycm): 2016
CT abdomen pelvis with oral contrast only.
HISTORY: Postop day 8 low anterior resection with loop ileostomy, had fascial dehiscence yesterday. Now postop day exploratory laparotomy and fascial closure. Elevated white count today. Evaluate for intra-abdominal infection.
COMPARISON: Preoperative CT 5-12-2014.
PRELIM RESIDENT INTERPRETATION:
Postoperative day one ventral abdominal surgery for wound dehiscence. Ill-defined attenuation between water and blood posterior to the left rectus may represent a postoperative hematoma. Abscess and/or superinfection is not excluded. No additional clinical findings. These findings were discussed with Dr. Bommiasamy of surgery at 4:21 p.m.
FINDINGS:
ABDOMEN: Bilateral passive lower lobe atelectasis-collapse due to mucus plugging. Tiny right effusion. Foci of hyperdense material within the atelectatic lungs suggest aspirated material. Enteric tube coiled within a hiatal hernia above the esophageal hiatus. Moderate underlying emphysema. Prior median sternotomy. Inferior left ventricular myocardial infarct-aneurysm unchanged. Unenhanced liver is grossly unremarkable. No focal lesion corresponding to a hypervascular segment 7 hemangioma seen on recent CT is evident. Gallbladder, biliary system, pancreas, spleen, and adrenal glands are unremarkable. Renal cortical and parapelvic cysts again noted. Stable nonobstructing 2 mm left upper pole calculus.
PELVIS: Bladder collapsed with indwelling Foley catheter. Prostate remains enlarged. Low anterior resection staple line anastomosis noted. Left lower quadrant approach pelvic surgical drain courses in the presacral space. There is trace loculated left posterolateral pelvic focus of postoperative fluid (image 167), 11 x 21 mm. No other focal intra-abdominal or pelvic collection. Scattered foci of postoperative pneumoperitoneum compatible with recent exploratory laparotomy. There is a right midabdominal diverting loop ileostomy. No bowel obstruction. Colon and distal ileum decompressed. Long segment cutaneous incisional dehiscence noted with 3 lower abdominal superficial retention sutures. Gauze packing is noted within the dehiscent incision. Subjacent fascial closure it appears intact following recent closure. Asymmetric enlargement of the left rectus muscle bulging posteriorly may be due to generalized edema hemorrhage. No destructive osseous lesion. Prior posterior L5 laminectomy and fusion with rod and pedicle screws.
Impression:
Extensive dependent lower lobe atelectasis and mucous plugging with hyperdense parenchymal punctate foci suggesting aspirated material.
Postoperative changes as above without drainable abscess.
Asymmetric left rectus muscle heterogeneous enlargement likely by combination of edema and hemorrhage.
Primary Diagnostic Code:
Primary Interpreting Staff: NORA DOBOS, MD (Verifier) /ND

Report Status: Verified Date Reported: JUN 26, 2014 Date Verified: JUN 26, 2014 Verifier E-Sig:/ES/CHUNG HOON LEE MD
Report: INDICATION: Presurgical clearance
REST: CTD/Vol 2.28 mGy
DLP 39 mGy*cm
10.1 mCi of technetium 99 M sestamibi (Cardiolite)
STRESS: CTD/Vol 2.53 mGy
DLP 49 mGy*cm
34.4 mCi of technetium 99 M sestamibi (Cardiolite)
PROCEDURE:
After a TIME OUT was observed, risks and benefits were explained to the patient and consent was obtained, IV access was placed, and Tc 99m sestamibi (Cardiolite) were injected. After a delay, rest gated SPECT images were obtained. The patient returned for the stress portion of the exam, and an EKG, baseline heart rate, blood pressure were done, and serial heart rate, blood pressure, and EKG tracings were obtained while 0.4 mg of regadenoson (Lexiscan) was injected. Subsequently Technetium 99m sestamibi (Cardiolite) were injected.
The patient then received 75 mg of aminophylline.
After a delay, gated stress SPECT images were obtained.
A low dose noncontrast nondiagnostic CT for the purposes of attenuation correction and gross anatomic localization was also performed.
COMPARISONS: 2/21/2007
FINDINGS:
Fixed perfusion defect involving the mid to basilar into wall likely RCA territory infarct.
Small region of mild reversibility in the inferolateral apex likely distal wraparound LAD ischemia.
Basilar inferior wall akinesis
Raw images do not demonstrate abnormal uptake within the lung fields.
The right ventricle is grossly normal in size.
REST:
LVEDV: 121 ml
LVESV: 50 ml
LVEF: 59 %
STRESS:
LVEDV: 123 ml
LVESV: 62 ml
LVEF: 50 %
TID: 1.14
Impression:
Pharmacologic stress test
Small region of mild ischemia in the likely distal wrap around LAD, slight progression since 2007
Infarct in the basilar inferior wall likely RCA, unchanged since 2007
Left ventricular ejection fraction is normal with basilar inferior wall akinesis, unchanged since 2007
