LN136,FN136 MN136 SSN136 DOB-DOB136 M Exm Date: MAY 12, 2014@09:18 Req Phys: KOWALSKI,DANIELLE F Pat Loc: EUS-4A103 (Req'g Loc) Img Loc: CAT SCAN-X Service: Unknown
(Case 229 COMPLETE) CT (THORAX) CHEST W/CONTRAST (CT Detailed) CPT:71260 Contrast Media : Non-ionic Iodinated Reason for Study: r/o mets
(Case 230 COMPLETE) CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS W/CONTRAST (CT Detailed) CPT:74177 Contrast Media : Non-ionic Iodinated
Clinical History: pt w/ proximal rectal cancer. Needs CT chest/abd/pelvis to r/o mets
Report Status: Verified Date Reported: MAY 12, 2014 Date Verified: MAY 12, 2014 Verifier E-Sig:/ES/JEFFREY JAMES HOM
Report: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, with contrast, 5/12/2014.
HISTORY: Evaluate for metastases, in patient with proximal rectal cancer.
COMPARISON: CT chest, dated 2/10/2005 and 7/29/2004; renal ultrasound, 11/27/2006; abdominal aortic ultrasound, 3/10/2010. No available prior cross-sectional sectional imaging of abdomen/pelvis.
TECHNIQUE: Following uneventful intravenous administration of 100 mL of Ultravist-370 and oral barium sulfate suspension, multiple contiguous axial CT images of chest and abdomen obtained, with coronal and sagittal reformats. CTDI: 34 mGy; DLP: 1621 mGycm.
FINDINGS:
CHEST:
Respiratory motion degrades images. Moderate centrilobular emphysema, upper lobe-predominant. Minimal anterior subpleural left upper lobe groundglass opacities, consistent with atelectasis versus pleural and parental scarring, adjacent with respect to coronary artery bypass graft. No change, since 2/10/2005, in minimal linear atelectasis versus scarring within lingula/left lung base. Lungs otherwise clear.
No effusions or lymphadenopathy. Normal heart size. Status post coronary artery bypass graft. Moderate-sized hiatal hernia.
ABDOMEN/PELVIS:
Diffuse hepatic steatosis. Hypervascular lesions with peripheral enhancement, measuring up to 1.3 cm in diameter within the anterior subcapsular left liver lobe (image 89, series 3), and up to 2.0 cm within the posterior liver dome (image 94, series 3) are consistent (based on their morphology and enhancement characteristics) with benign liver hemangiomas; these two liver hemangiomas are unchanged compared with the CT chest with contrast from 7/29/2004. No other liver lesions. Liver is normal in size and smooth in contour. Minimal focal fatty infiltration at falciform ligament insertion. Biliary tract, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, and adrenals unremarkable.
Mild bilateral renal cortical thinning; bilateral renal cysts (the majority of which are parapelvic; the largest non-parapelvic cyst is exophytic from the posterior interpolar right kidney). Tiny, punctate, 2 mm calculus within interpolar left kidney. No solid renal masses, bilaterally. Bladder nondistended. Severe prostatomegaly.
Visualized bowel is of normal caliber. Reported rectal cancer not clearly discernible on current exam. Normal appendix. No ascites or lymphadenopathy. Extensive atherosclerosis within nonaneurysmal abdominal aorta (within which there is concentric mural thrombus within its infrarenal aspect). Principal branch vessels arising from abdominal aorta appear patent. Fat-containing periumbilical hernia, that does not contain bowel.
MUSCULOSKELETAL:
Grade 2 anterolisthesis of L5 on S1; discogenic degenerative changes at L5-S1. Status post posterior spinal fusion at L4-S1, with bilateral transpedicular screws at each of these levels. No obvious evidence of hardware loosening or failure. Status post median sternotomy. Osteopenia. Bone, healed posterior left seventh and eighth rib fractures. No destructive bony lesions. Mild bilateral gynecomastia.
Impression:
No evidence of metastatic disease.
Severe emphysema.
Moderate hiatal hernia.
Hepatic steatosis.
Bilateral renal cortical thinning, in setting of severe prostatomegaly. Recommend clinical correlation with any signs or symptoms of bladder outlet obstruction.
Primary Diagnostic Code:
Primary Interpreting Staff: JEFFREY JAMES HOM, M.D. (Verifier) /JJH

SIGMOID COLON AND RECTUM 2. RECTAL DONUT Brief Clinical History: T2 N0 M1 mid rectal cancer. Preoperative Diagnosis: Mid rectal cancer. Operative Findings: No data provided. Postoperative Diagnosis: Mid rectal cancer. GROSS DESCRIPTION: INTRAOPERATIVE CONSULTATION:
FS1: SIGMOID COLON AND RECTUM: DISTAL MARGIN 1.8 CM FROM TATTOO.
Diagnosis rendered by:
DARIUS K. AMJADI, M.D., J.D. STAFF PATHOLOGIST - PATHOLOGY AND LAB MED
Specimen #1, received fresh for frozen section diagnosis, labeled with the patient's name, social security number and "sigmoid colon and rectum", consists of a 25.0 cm in length x 2.5 cm in diameter portion of colon and rectum. The margins are stapled closed on both ends with a stitch marking the distal portion of the colon. The attached mesenteric fat is abundant, roughly 3.5 cm thick. The mesorectum is bulky and grossly intact. The estimated diameter is 5.0 cm and with the mesorectum/true proximal margin extends up 4.0 cm in length from the distal aspect of the specimen. The staples are removed from both margins and inked black. The mesorectal margin is also inked black. On opening of the colon there is a 2.9 x 2.0 cm mucosal tattoo located 1.8 cm from the distal margin. There is a firm palpable mass at the center of that tattoo estimated to be 0.4 x 0.4 cm. The lesion is not raised or excoriated. Additionally on the mucosal surface there is a 0.5 x 0.4 x 0.3 cm mucosal polyp located 3.5 cm from the proximal margin. Serially sectioning of the lesion reveals a homogenous firm black cut surface to a lesion as well as an area of underlying serosal thickening. The firm black lesion does not appear to grossly invade the muscularis propria. Additionally there is a 0.3 x 0.3 firm nodule on the mucosal surface located 6.5 cm proximal to the inked lesion and 11.3 cm from distal margin. The attached fat is serially sectioned and searched for lymph nodes and all possible lymph nodes are submitted.
Cassette 1A, representative section of proximal margin Cassette 1B-1C, representative section of distal margin Cassette 1D-1E, representative section of lesion at area of greatest depth Cassette 1F, longitudinal section from inked lesion to distal margin, including black inked mesorectal margin Cassette 1G, additional representative section of lesion Cassette 1H, representative section of polyp and second firm mucosal nodule Cassette 1I-1P, possible lymph nodes
Specimen #2, received in formalin, labeled with the patient's name, social security number, and "rectal donut", consists of an unoriented 2.4 x 1.8 x 1.0 cm piece of tan-pink tissue consistent with rectal donut. There is a 2.9 x 1.8 cm piece of skin covering one side of the specimen with a 0.3 cm in diameter circular opening. The specimen is radially sectioned and completely submitted.
Cassette 2A-2B, rectal donut

2. COLON, POLYP AT 30 CM, WITH STOCK-1CM, POLYPECTOMY: - TUBULAR ADENOMA; FREE OF MARGINS.
3. RECTUM, POLYP AT RECTUM-12MM, POLYPECTOMY: - INVASIVE MODERATELY TO FOCALLY POORLY-DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA ARISING FROM A TUBULAR ADENOMA; SEE COMMENT. - THE INVASIVE ADENOCARCINOMA APPROXIMATES THE CAUTERIZED TISSUE EDGE. - FOCI SUSPICIOUS FOR LYMPHOVASCULAR INVASION ARE IDENTIFIED.
4. RECTUM, BIOPSY TISSUE AROUND RECTAL POLYP, BIOPSY: - RECTAL MUCOSA WITH NO DIAGNOSTIC ALTERATIONS, INCLUDING NO DYSPLASIA OR CARCINOMA IDENTIFIED.
Comment: Part 3 consists of an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal poorly differentiated areas characterized by invasive single malignant cells. The adenocarcinoma is arising from a tubular adenoma. Also there are foci suspicious for lymphovascular invasion. Part 3 received intradepartmental consultation by Dr. Kirsten Woolf who concurs with the above diagnosis for part 3. The results were discussed with Dr. Judith Collins on 5/1/2014.
PHYSICIAN NOTIFIED BY VISTA EMAIL.
Slide(s) reviewed and diagnosis rendered by:
